content: Hi, my dear friend (yes, it’s you!), welcome to my blog. This is your truly, Fudong Wang, who currently works as a postdoc at UCF (supervised by Alexander Tovbis). My dissertation mentor is Wen-Xiu Ma. My research interests include classical soliton theory ( inverse scattering, long-time asymptotics) and (currently) spectral theory of soliton/breather gases. Besides integrable system, I am also interested in complex analysis related problem, such as classic potential theory, free boundary problems and uniform algebra.
summary: Hi, my dear friend (yes, it’s you!), welcome to my blog. This is your truly, Fudong Wang, who currently works as a postdoc at UCF (supervised by Alexander Tovbis). My dissertation mentor is Wen-Xiu Ma.
title: Fudong Wang

content:
Hi, my dear friend (yes, it’s you!), welcome to my blog. This is your truly, Fudong Wang, who currently works as a postdoc at UCF (supervised by Alexander Tovbis). My dissertation mentor is Wen-Xiu Ma. My research interests include classical soliton theory ( inverse scattering, long-time asymptotics) and (currently) spectral theory of soliton/breather gases. Besides integrable system, I am also interested in complex analysis related problem, such as classic potential theory, free boundary problems and uniform algebra.
 This is me 👇     Current projects  Study the thermodynamic limit of densities and fluxies for the fNLS soliton/breather gases. General problem on well-posedness of the nonlinear dispersion relation for soliton/breather gases. Statistical properties of the landscape of finite-gap solutions for fNLS.   Publications   Recent developments in spectral theory of focusing NLS soliton gases (in preparing, with Alex)
  A $\bar\partial$-Steepest Descent Method for Oscillatory Riemann–Hilbert Problems, Journal of Nonlinear Science 32 (1), 1-46, 2022 (with Wen-Xiu Ma)
  A Note on Electrified Droplets, Computational Methods and Function Theory, 1-27, 2021 (with Nathan Hayford)
   Talks (under constructing) Integrable Systems and Random Matrix Theory Seminar @ University of Michigan}  Oct, 2021, A dbar-steepest descent analysis for the long-time asymptotic behavior of oscillatory Riemann-Hilbert problems  Integrable system seminar @ UCF  Aug, 2021, Continuum limit of theta functions. Jan, 2022, Integral equation of the first kind with logarithmic kernel.  Differential Equations Seminar Talks @ University of South Florida}  Sep, 2020, Derivation of the NLS equation from Maxwell’s Equations Apr, 2020, $L^2$-bijectivity of scattering and inverse scattering in some Sobolev spaces. Oct, 2019, $\bar{\partial}$ method and its application to nonlinear evolution equations. Sep, 2019, Inverse scattering and N-soliton solution for the nonlocal nonlinear Schrödinger equation. Apr, 2019, Riemann-Hilbert problems for two-component coupled mKdV systems. Mar, 2019, Asymptotic solutions of the nonlinear Schrödinger equation based on conservation laws. Oct, 2018, The emergence of solitons of the Korteweg-de Vries Equation from sufficiently decaying initial conditions. Apr, 2018, Nonlinear steepest descent method for long-time asymptotic for MKdV. Mar, 2017, Riemann-Hilbert problems with zeros.  On Graduate Math @ USF  Oct, 2021, The Continuum Limit of Theta Functions. March, 2021, A short Introduction to the Theta Functions. May, 2020, An elementary introduction to Fredholm Determinant. Mar, 2020, Introduction to the Riemann-Hilbert Problem in $L^p$-space. Oct, 2019, What is … inverse scattering? Sep, 2019, An Introduction to the Riemann-Hilbert Problems on the real line. Jun, 2019, Some fundamental formulas(Plemelj-Privalov) on the Cauchy-type integrals.   Teaching As a Grader  MAC 2283 — ENGINEERING CALCULUS III COP 4313 — SYMBOLIC COMPUTATIONS IN MATHEMATICS MAD 4401 — NUMERICAL ANALYSIS I MAA 4212 — INTERMEDIATE ANALYSIS II MAP 4341 — INTRODUCTION TO PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS  As an Instructor  MAS 3106 — Linear Algebra: Concentrated on proofs, abstract linear algebra. MAS 3105 — Matrix and Linear Algebra: Concentrated on computation side of matrix, QR decomposition, determinants, projections, least-square approximation. MAC 2312 — CALCULUS II: Integrals, Techniques of Integration, Applications of Integration, Series.   References  Alexander Tovbis @ UCF Wen-Xiu Ma @ USF Evguenii Rakhmanov @ USF Seung-Yeop Lee @ USF Dmitry Khavinson @ USF

summary: An example of using Wowchemy's Book layout for publishing online courses.
title: 📊 Learn Data Science

content:
Build a foundation in Python.
  1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks
Learn   Quiz What is the difference between lists and tuples? Lists
 Lists are mutable - they can be changed Slower than tuples Syntax: a_list = [1, 2.0, 'Hello world']  Tuples
 Tuples are immutable - they can’t be changed Tuples are faster than lists Syntax: a_tuple = (1, 2.0, 'Hello world')   Is Python case-sensitive? Yes
title: Python basics

content:
Learn how to visualize data with Plotly.
  1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks
Learn   Quiz When is a heatmap useful? Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
 Write Plotly code to render a bar chart import plotly.express as px data_canada = px.data.gapminder().query("country == 'Canada'") fig = px.bar(data_canada, x='year', y='pop') fig.show()
summary: Learn how to visualize data with Plotly.
title: Visualization

content:
Introduction to statistics for data science.
  1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks
Learn The general form of the normal probability density function is:
$$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi} } e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2} $$
 The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution. $\sigma$ is its standard deviation. The variance of the distribution is $\sigma^{2}$.   Quiz What is the parameter $\mu$? The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution.
summary: Introduction to statistics for data science.
title: Statistics

content:
这是4年前买的眼镜，Warby Parker牌的。
就在前几日， 我心血来潮，嫌弃这眼镜有点镜片有点磨损的厉害，便想着该换了。
验光完的第二天，在我擦拭镜片的时候，发现左边的金属边框有个若隐若现的裂缝。当时不以为然。
过了两日，又去 Warby Parker 的门店光顾。选了新的镜架。然需要等待2到3周。记得4年前，最多也就等了一周吧。是公司的业务量上去了还是疫情的影响呢？
又过了两日，刚睡醒的我又擦拭起了我的眼镜。“铛”，左边的镜片掉落，那边框也断了。正是那个几天前我不在意的小裂缝。难道是它知道有新的它会替代它，所以自行“罢工”了？
新眼镜还需等待两周， 旧的眼镜又罢了工，只能用上我那带度数的墨镜。戴上墨镜，世界一下子就暗了下来。想着明天还得教课，脑子里面画面感十足的播放着上课的情形， 不免有些紧张却又期待。
回到我这戴了4年的眼镜。想想，这也是一段不短的陪伴了。想想，我这四年看的东西，都是穿过它的两片镜片。想想，这四年又有多少失去联系的朋友。想想，还有多少我不以为然的“小裂缝”。
再见了，我的眼镜。

content:
曾做了好多奇怪的梦。现在却也忘记的差不多了。
有几个梦是重复的。
又一次， 我梦到我开车行驶在沿海公路（或许是跨海公路）， 路的左边是山， 右边是悬崖，悬崖下面就是大海。 大概就是加州一号公路的样子。那个梦好像也发生在那次旅行后不久。
那不是一个好梦。一开始，风和日丽；下一秒竟然骤雨狂风。是一个末日之类的梦。梦境其实很真实。我开着开着，右边的公路开始坠落，天空忽然也变得晦暗， 海浪也是异常的汹涌。 路边的漂亮房子被这海浪一口一口的吞噬。
我不记得副驾有没有人， 也不记得我当时的心情。人做梦的时候会有心情吗？
我就一直开，一直开，仿佛只要我不承认世界末日， 那滔天的巨浪就是小小的浪花而已。
不知道何时，我醒来了。醒来的时候并不觉得惊喜，似乎还满喜悦。
大概是我觉得梦境本就不真实，相比于显示，梦里面的世纪末日无非是种电影院的体验。
有人会觉得梦在预示这什么， 我不知道这个梦到底想要告诉我什么。现在，我甚至觉得这是我编造的梦。
梦和谎言，哪一个会更加真实一点，我们不得而知。
于我而言，梦里没有谎言，没有道德，没有伤害，没有感情。
summary: 曾做了好多奇怪的梦。现在却也忘记的差不多了。
title: 关于梦境

content:
Background Integral equations play important roles in mathematical physics. In this short note, we are going to discuss a class of integral equation of the first kind. My motivation to study those equations is from soliton gas, where the nonlinear dispersion relation is as follows: $$\int_\Gamma g(z,w)u(w)|dw|+\sigma(z)u(z)=\phi(z),\quad z\in \Gamma$$
where $\Gamma$ is some simple smooth rectifiable curve in $\mathbb{C}^+$ and kernel $g(z,w)=\log\left|\frac{z-\bar w}{z-w}\right|$ is so-called Green kernel (i.e. it is the Green function to the Direchlet problem on the upper half plane.). The case when $\sigma\equiv 0$ is referred to as soliton condensate. As one can immediately see, the equation becomes Fredholm equation of the first kind. It is well-known that integral equation of the first kind is (in general) ill-posed in the sense of Hadamard. Here we are going to consider a slightly different equation: $$\int_{\Gamma}\log|w-z|^{-1} u(w)|dw|=f(z),\quad z\in \Gamma.$$
And we will consider the uniqueness of the equation using classical potential theory. Then we will use a method introduced by Yan&Sloan to solve the equation explicitly.
Potential theory and uniqueness Let’s first introduce some definitions from classical complex analysis. All the definitions and theorems can be found on Hille’s book.
Definition 1. Let $\mu$ be a probability measure supported in $\Gamma$ (i.e. $\mu(\Gamma)=1$.), the logarithmic potential is $$U^{\mu}(z)=-\int_\Gamma \log\left|z-w\right|d\mu(w),\quad z\in \mathbb{C}.$$
Definition 2. The energy is defined as $$I(\mu)=\int U^{\mu}(z) d\mu(z).$$
Definition 3. The capacity of a compact set $\Gamma$ is defined as $$C_\Gamma=e^{-V_\Gamma}=\exp{(-\inf_{\mu\in M(\Gamma)}I(\mu))},$$ where $V_\Gamma$ is so-called Robin constant.
Definition 4. A charge is a signed measure, which always has the decomposition as $\sigma=\sigma_+-\sigma_-$, where $\sigma_\pm$ are called positive and negative part of the charge. And we denote the space of charge with finite energy as $S(\Gamma)$.
Now let’s list some classical results from Hille’s book.
Lemma 1. Let $\Gamma$ be a compact set with positive capacity, ans $S\subset\Gamma$ has zero capacity. If $\mu\in M(\Gamma)$ and $I(\mu)<\infty$, then $\mu(S)=0$. The same statement if also true for charges (exercise).
Lemma 2. If $C_\Gamma>0$, then there is a unique measure $\mu_e$ such that $I(\mu_e)=\inf_{\mu\in M(\Gamma)}I(\mu)$.
Lemma 3. Let $\Gamma$ be a compact set with positive capacity. Then $U^{\mu_e}(z)\leq V_\Gamma,\quad z\in \mathbb{C}$ and $U^{\mu_e}(z)= V_\Gamma,\quad z\in \Gamma, q.e.$.
Lemma 4. Let $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ and $\sigma(\Gamma)=0$. Then $I(\sigma)\geq 0$ and “$=$” iff $\sigma\equiv 0$.
Based on the lemmas we mentioned above, we can easily prove the following theorem.
Theorem 1. Let $\Gamma$ be compact and $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ generates constant potential, i.e. $U^{\sigma}(z)=c,z\in \Gamma$, q.e., then $c=\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma$ and $\sigma=\sigma(\Gamma)\mu_e$.
proof. Write \red{$\sigma=\sigma(\Gamma)\mu_e+\sigma_0$}, then $\sigma_0(\Gamma)=0$ and it belongs to $S(\Gamma)$. Thus for each $z\in \Gamma$, we have $$ U^{\sigma_0}(z)=c-\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma, q.e. $$ Then $$ I(\sigma_0)=(c-\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma)\sigma_0(\Gamma)=0. $$ By lemma 4, $\sigma_0\equiv 0$, and the result follows.
Corollary 1. Suppose $\Gamma$ is compact with $C_\Gamma\neq 1$, if $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ is such that $U^\sigma(z)=0,z\in \Gamma, q.e.$, then $\sigma\equiv 0$.
Theorem 2.(Uniqueness) Let $\Gamma$ be a piecewise smooth with finite length and $C_\Gamma\neq 1$, assume $g\in L_p(\Gamma)$ with $p>1$ such that \begin{align*} -\int_\Gamma \log|z-w| g(w)|dw|=0,\quad \forall z\in \Gamma, \end{align*} then $g\equiv 0$.
Solution Methods We are now in the position to construct the solution. The method is due to Yan-Sloan, see reference[3] for more details. The existence will follow as we find a way to construct it. First, let’s recall some notations for Sobolev spaces.
Let $C^\infty_e$ denote the set of even smooth $2\pi$ periodic functions on $\mathbb{R}$. For each $v\in C_e^\infty$, we have \begin{align*} v(s)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\left(\sum_{m\in\mathbb Z_+}\hat v(m)\cos{ms}+\frac{1}{2}\hat v(0)\right), \end{align*} with $ \hat v(m)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int_0^\pi v(s)\cos{(ms)}ds, m=0,1,2,\cdots. $ Define the weighted norm in terms of the Fourier series: \begin{align*} |v|^2_t=2\sum_{m\in \mathbb{Z}_+} m^{2t}|\hat v(m)|^2+|\hat v(0)|^2. \end{align*} Definition [Weighted Sobolev space] $$H_e^t(2\pi) = \text{Closure}\{C_e^\infty(2\pi),|\cdot|_t\}.$$
To connect it to our equation, we recall the following well-know indenty: For any $v\in H^0(2\pi)$, we have \begin{align*} -\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi\log\left|2e^{-1/2}\sin\frac{t-\tau}{2}\right|v(\tau)d\tau=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\sum_{|m|>0}\frac{\hat v(m)}{|m|}e^{imt}+\hat v(0)\right):=Av(t). \end{align*}
The operator $A$ defined above has very good properties. In fact, $A$ is an unitary operator from …

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Wowchemy Wowchemy | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  **Two**  Three   A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions? Ask
Documentation
